strDesc: [us] flicks through the local social networks on their PDA.
[us] pulls up their schedule and updates their to-do list.
[us] sobs quietly to themself.
[us] pauses to add a line to a long letter home on their PDA.
[us] loads the [them] with a coffee puck.
The [us] emits a jet of coffee flavoured water into [them]'s canteen.
[us] savours the first sip of coffee.
Something inside the housing whirrs, then grinds, then fizzles. [them] sighs. The damned [us] is on the fritz again.
[us] hits the bloody [them] to get it to work again.
The [us] shudders and sputters, drooling liquid. It's still broken.
[us] flips open the [them]'s housing and sets about fixing it.
The [us] begins working again, and [them] jams their canteen in the socket in the nick of time.
Something inside the [us] crunches pitifully, suggesting that the [us] is now broken beyond immediate repair.
[us] throws up their hands. Coffee isn't happening. Everyone had better stay out of their way.

[us] steps aside, to make room for [them].
[us] warns [them] off.

[us] throws up their hands and gives up.

[us] steps towards [them], threateningly, displaying symbols of authority.

[us] shoots the breeze with [them].
[us] snubs [them], and walks away.

[us] grows a little agitated, and stamps their butt under foot.
[us] accepts the cigarette and [them]'s offered light.
[us] isn't interested in smoking.
[us] and [them] enjoy their smoking session in a comfortable silence.
[us] and [them] enjoy a smoking session full of cordial banter.
[us] and [them] enjoy close proximity, sensuous glances, shared breath, and a lick of double entendre as they smoke.
[us]'s conversation falters, and ends with [us] and [them] in silent reflection, puffing away.
[us] waves the offered Viceroy away. It's not their brand.
[us] does a stupid trick for [them].
[us] eyes [them] and scoffs, "Decided it was a no pants day today?"
[us] makes a disgusted face at [them]. "Ugh, you're a mess!"
[us] exclaims excitedly.

[us] starts telling [them] old war stories.
[us] is reminded of a strange, compelling story and they tell it at length.
[us] rolls their eyes and sighs.

[us] re-enacts a play from the last game, hurling an imaginary ball to [them].
[us] and [them] reminisce about how the Shooters destroyed the Warriors.'
[us] gloats to [them] about how the Warriors destroyed [them]'s precious Shooters.
[us] catches the ball. Dipping and juking, they beat three defenders and shoot at a bulkhead for the goal.

[us] spectacularly fumbles the ball. [them] boos.

strTitle: Name Drop Your Law Enforcement Contact
strDesc: [us] says that Officer [3rd] has caught wind of some of [them]'s dealings. But seeing as Officer [3rd] is a friend, [us] might be able to throw them off the scent. Assuming [them] is willing to play nice.

strDesc: [us] asks [them] if [3rd] has been around here lately. They're a close personal friend.
[us] insults [them].

[us] insults [them] viciously.
[us] insults [them] viciously.

[us] subtracts one month salary from death pay.

[us] cuts the negotiation short and tells [them] that nobody's gonna tell them what to do anymore. They'd rather be their own boss.
[us] tells [them] that they work best solo.
[us] cuts the negotiation short and says nobody respects them in a team setting, so they'd rather not join a crew.

[us] cuts the negotiation short and says the job is far too dangerous.

[us] cuts the negotiation short and says they'd bring the ship down anyway. So no.

strTitle: Tell them to Fuck Off Forever
strDesc: [us] tells [them] to fuck off. Forever.
[us] tries to convince [them] to stay in the crew.
[us] tells [them] to take this job and shove it. Nobody's gonna tell them what to do anymore.
[us] says nobody respects them on this ship.
[us] says the job is too dangerous. They're out.
[us] says it's just best if they leave. They're just bringing the ship down anyway.

strTitle: Ask Them to Stay on the Crew
strDesc: [us] asks [them] to remain a member of the crew based on new terms.
[us] says [they] should stick around if they know what's good for them. Space is a dangerous place for people without friends.
[us] says [them] has been very impressive lately and offers some new, vital jobs onboad if [them] agrees to stay.

strTitle: Add $1000 to a One Time Bonus
strDesc: [us] adds $1000 to a one time bonus.
[us] adds $25 per day to [them]'s current salary.
[us] adds one month salary to [them]'s death pay.
[us] describes a few of the harsh economic realities in the system and suggests that [them] doesn't have the skills to find a better position than the one they have now.
[us] says they'd rather work with a crew that values their input and contributions. They quit, and the decision is final.
[us] says they don't want to spend their final moments on this ship. They quit, and the decision is final.
[us] says they'd rather work with a crew that values their input and contributions. They quit, and the decision is final.
[us] says they'd rather work with a crew that values their input and contributions. They quit, and the decision is final.
[us] quits.
[us] says they appreciate having a more integral role onboard. They accept the new terms and agree to stay.
After calming down a bit, [us] decides to stay onboard for now.

strTitle: Remain on Crew out of Fear
strDesc: [us] shrinks away and agrees that [them] probably knows what is best. [them] will remain a member of the crew for now.
[us] tells [them] to double fuck off.
[us] is grateful for their time with [them].
[us] asks the officers if there is a problem.
[us] asks [them] if they know why they have been boarded.
[us] opens the UI.
[us] offers a warm greeting and asks [them] how they have been since they last spoke.
[us] says they can't complain and asks how long [them] has been flying around this bucket of bolts.
[us] asks [them] what spacers have been talking about in the criminal underworld.
[us] says they are beginning to think that the Black Market fixer who hangs out in The Mescaform is actually on the Ayotimiwa payroll.
[us] says they heard that a bunch of roughnecks are slapping a dozen thrusters on old salvage pods and doing circuit races around an asteroid field twenty klicks out from K-Leg.

[us] says they heard kids are trying to summon The Mariner on purpose.
They're putting on purple jumpsuits and smoking like two ounces of Damask Rose.
Now half the abandoned shops in the Old Emporium smell like bongwater and BO.
[us] asks [them] if the suits at Ayotimiwa are up to their old tricks.

[us] says that Harbourmaster Adeyemi just built a new wing on his place in the NoCo Villas.
It has a private port in the case the Big Man needs a quick exit.
He's growing more paranoid by the day. Thinks every slamming door is the inaugural gunshot of La Revolucion.

[us] says the more puritanical Ayo execs are squawking about shuttering the Old Emporium again.
Something about productivity loss.
What those humps don't realize is the Mescaform is the only reason spacers on this rock don't kill eachother.
Not too often, anyway.

[us] says the fines for illegal salvage are scheduled to go up again next year.
Ayo loves the resale business, but you better believe they are going to find out exactly how much they can squeeze you without making you stop.
[us] asks [them] if they've confiscated anything good lately.

[us] says some headcase on the shipbreaker floor killed his boss with the first tool he could find. Guy confessed immediately so the murder weapon is of no evidentiary value. [them] can have it if they want.
[us] says why not? Guy clearly doesn't need it anymore.
[us] hands over the tool, tells [them] not to do anything too stupid with it, and heads back to their patrol ship.

[us] says thanks but they don't need a tool that badly.
[them] shrugs, then departs for their patrol vehicle.

[us] says they pulled security detail for Ayo exec party up in NoCo and it was quite the soiree.
The host gave them a case of leftover booze as a parting gift.
Want it?
[us] says hell yeah. Love drinking on the boss's dime.
[us] hands over the booze and tells [them] to take it easy.

[us] says thanks but they don't need that much booze on a ship.
[them] wishes [us] good luck and heads back to their patrol ship.
[us] flashes a maniacal grin and tells [them] this one won't go down easy.

strTitle: Ask for Their Badge and Credentials
strDesc: [us] asks to see [them]'s badge and security license.
[us] attempts to change the mood of [them] via another angle.
[us] attempts to change the mood of [them] via another angle.
[us] tells [them] that their uniform is their credential.
[us] says to take a step back.
[us] flashes [them] a legitimate seeming badge.
[us] promises they will write an incident report of the docking upon return to their cruiser.
[us] quickly returns the badge to their inner pocket.
[us] thanks the officer for being so diligent and suggests that AyoSec is the only thing keeping the OKLG system from falling into chaos.
[us] agrees wholeheartedly and says they appreciate meeting someone who understands the role of the badge. They let [them] off with a warning and wish them a pleasant day.
[us] sees through [them]'s shameless ass-kissing, and continues with their protocol.
[us] says they need a minute to think.

strTitle: Admit to Having No Active Transponder
strDesc: [us] says they know that they were flying dark.
[us] says it is illegal and highly dangerous to fly without an actively broadcasting transponder.

strTitle: Make Up a Plausible Excuse for Flying Dark
strDesc: [us] invents a reason for flying dark that would be reasonable if it were true.
[us] accepts the excuse and tells [them] to be more careful in the future.
[us] doesn't buy the excuse and instead renders [them] a fine for flying dark.

strTitle: Make a Joke about Flying Dark
strDesc: [us] makes light of the fact that they are flying dark, and even makes a little joke about the situation.
[us] laughs and banters back before letting [them] off with a warning.
[us] says flying dark is nothing to joke about and renders [them] a significant fine.
[us] says [them] is flying a ship that has been reported stolen. The officer brings [them] into AyoSec custody.
[us] says that they have their Ogiso's work safety poster prominitently displayed in a high traffic area as per local regulations.

strTitle: Confirm They are Doing Random Ogiso Inspection
strDesc: [us] confirms that they are doing a routine Ogiso's inspection.
[us] says it seems like the crew has made a good faith effort to follow regulations and lets [them] off with a warning.
[us] says the crew has not been following Ogiso's regulations and issues a minor fine of $1500 to [them].
[us] pays the fine and asks [them] what the Ogiso boot tastes like.
[us] pays the fine and says they are happy that Ogiso has their back.
[us] says this is more serious than some petty regulation
[us] tries to bait [them] into an easy win over a small infraction.

strTitle: Admit that the Ship Is Not Yet Spaceworthy
strDesc: [us] says that the ship is a bit of a work in progress
[us] confirms that the hull does not pass basic inspection and issues a minor fine of $1000 to [them].
[us] pays the fine and insists that while an ugly ship can be repaired the same can't be said for [them]'s face.
[us] pays the fine and thanks [them] for their service.
[us] says they don't care how busted the ship is.
[us] admits that they docked in order to salvage the derelict.

strTitle: Confirm That Salvage Operation is Illegal
strDesc: [us] confirms that [them] is performing illegal salvage. [us] fines [them] in the amount of $15000.
[us] fishes out their salvage license and presents it to [them].

[us] takes the license from [them], examines it a minute, then hands it back.
Making a note of the exchange, [us] thanks [them] for their time, and turns to leave.
[us] pays the fine while telling the officers exactly what animals they resemble.
[us] pays the fine tells the officers to fly safe.
[us] says they don't care what scrappers do with junk in the boneyard.
[us] says they have no idea why they've been boarded.
"Wait a minute," [us] says, looking at [them].
"Mmm-hmm," [us] exhales, unimpressed.
[us] look pensive, like they're considering something.

[us] says [them] was randomly selected for boarding investigation, but all appears to be in order here.
Making a note of the incident, [us] thanks [them] for their time, and turns to leave.
[us] suggests they may have some previously unpaid fines they've been meaning to settle...
[us] adds $500 to a potential bribe.
[us] subtracts $500 from a potential bribe.
[us] offers [them] a bribe to make this all go away.
[us] scoffs at [them]'s offer and demands they hand over what they're carrying.
[us] adds the bribe to their ledger and wishes [them] a pleasant day.
[us] grins, adds the bribe to their ledger, and gives [them] their contact info in case they ever need a 'friend' in the near future.
[us] tells [them] they are worth more than that.
[us] declines the bribe and demands that [them] shows more respect for the badge.
[us] declines the bribe and insists that while it may not feel like it all the time around here, some people take their job seriously.
[us] appears annoyed that the situation is out of their control. They scowl at [them], fuming in silence.
[us] appears on-edge, and demands that [them] not make any sudden moves.
[us] reaches their boiling point and lashes out at [them] with a brutal reprimand.
[us] has completely lost their patience and says they aren't even going to waste any more time finding a legitimate infraction. [us] assigns [them] a hefty, bullshit fine.
[us] pays the fine while telling the officers exactly what animals they resemble.
[us] pays the fine tells the officers to fly safe.
[us] says that [them] should take AyoSec officers more seriously and demands that they hand over what they're carrying.
[us] asks [them] to tell them about their home.
[us] tells [them] they'd rather not talk about home.
[us] tells [them] that they are from Earth.

strTitle: Ask What Life is Like on Earth
strDesc: [us] asks [them] what life is like on Earth.

strTitle: Describe the Best Parts of Earth
strDesc: [us] says that it was as beautiful as everyone says. You could walk for fifty miles in a forest and still find more trees.

strTitle: Describe the Worst Parts of Earth
strDesc: [us] says that it was a rotten planet even before the ablation cascade cut it off from the rest of the system.

strTitle: Share a Childhood Memory from Earth
strDesc: [us] remembers a lake that would freeze in the winter and melt in the summer. There was a rope swing on the lake and a big rock you could climb and then leap from.
[us] tells [them] that they are from Mars.

strTitle: Ask What Life is Like on Mars
strDesc: [us] asks [them] what life is like on Mars.
[us] says that they grew up on Hangzhou Orbital, which is a paradise for those who can afford it. [us] hopes to one day have enough money to return there and buy a residential visa.

strTitle: Describe the Worst Parts of Mars
strDesc: [us] says that Tharsis Landing is riven by factional violence. Residents of The Labyrinth are constantly clashing with Martian Security, or else taking their bribes.
[us] recalls thousands of low single story homes surrounded green siheyuan courtyards. [us] would ride pedicabs down through the hutong because their parents wouldn't let them ride the metro.
[us] tells [them] that they are from Venus.

strTitle: Ask What Life is Like on Venus
strDesc: [us] asks [them] what life is like on Venus.
[us] says that life on a Venusian aerostat isn't so different than life on a big station. But Newcal is getting very crowded and [us] is excited for the upcoming launch of the aerostat Los Angeles.

strTitle: Describe the Worst Parts of Venus
strDesc: [us] says that the piracy around the Newcal aerostat colony is getting worse every day. If the crew refuses to cooperate, the pirates will force the entire ship down to the crushing atmosphere at Venus's surface.

[us] says they grew up watching the RCS drag races outside the Brazilian aerostat colony 'Cloudbreak.' The little coffins cut through the dense yellow sulfuric fog of the Venusian atmosphere like it wasn't even there.

strTitle: Say You Are from Jupiter System
strDesc: [us] tells [them] that they grew up near Jupiter.

strTitle: Ask What Region They are From
strDesc: [us] asks [them] what part of the Jovian system they are from.

strTitle: Talk About the Best Parts of Europa
strDesc: [us] says that they grew up in Atlantis, a submarine colony beneath the frozen oceans of Europa. [us] misses Europa, whose population mostly ignores the messy political and corporate drama of the inner planets.

strTitle: Talk About the Worst parts of Europa
strDesc: [us] says that they grew up in Atlantis, a submarine colony beneath the frozen oceans of Europa. [us] insists the cliffside colony was damp and miserable and full of researchers who were intentionally obtuse.

[us] says that they grew up in Atlantis, a submarine colony beneath the frozen oceans of Europa. [us] recalls a childhood trip to Point Mosman and the tendrilled iridescent Lusca drifting in and out of the thermal vents.

strTitle: Describe the Best Parts of Ganymede
strDesc: [us] says that they grew up on Ganymede, the only truly free colony left in the system. [us] misses the solidarity of building a liberated society among laboring Confederates.

strTitle: Describe the Worst Parts of Ganymede
strDesc: [us] says that they grew up on Ganymede, the only truly 'free' colony left in the system. [us] complains that it is impossible to get ahead there because the Confederacy won't let anyone start a private mining claim.

[us] says that they grew up on Ganymede, the only truly free colony left in the system. [us] recalls staring into the sky during the Coup and watching the Guns of Ganymede flash teal and pink as they obliterated a fleet of decelerating corporate mercenary frigates.
[us] asks [them] about their family.
[us] says they'd rather not talk about their family.
[us] says that they miss their parents who live back home.
[us] says that their mother passed away, but they remain close with their father.
[us] says that their father passed away, but they remain close with their mother.
[us] tells [them] that their parents are long gone. They consider themselves a kind of orphan.
[us] says they never knew their parents.
[us] says their Dad works on this station and is kind of a pain in the ass.
[us] says they take after their mother: easy to like, hard to love.
[us] says their father floats in and out of their life at his own leisure.
[us] tells [them] that they are an only child.
[us] tells [them] that they have many brothers and sisters.

strTitle: Talk about being close with siblings.
strDesc: [us] tells [them] that they are very close with one of their siblings.

strTitle: Talk about being close with siblings.
strDesc: [us] says they had a sibling who passed away under tragic circumstances.

strTitle: Talk about being close with siblings.
strDesc: [us] says their older brother is always trying to steal the limelight.
[us] says that they hope to have kids one day.
[us] says they have a kid who they worry about all the time.
[us] says they have two kids and they fight constantly.
[us] says their child has some special needs that cost a small fortune to accommodate. [us] insists the effort gives their own life greater purpose.
[us] pulls [them] aside and begins to disparage [3rd]'s character in great detail.
[us] agrees and says they've always hated [3rd], especially their awful smug face.
[us] glances away and says [3rd] isn't all that bad once you get used to them.

strTitle: Ask About Who They are Badmouthing
strDesc: [us] asks [them] to remind them who [3rd] is.

strTitle: Label Your Enemy as a Predator
strDesc: [us] says that [3rd] is a roving thug who, in the way of all cowards, only picks fights with people who don't have power.

strTitle: Label Your Enemy as a Liar
strDesc: [us] says [3rd] is a snake in the grass who will say one thing to your face and something completely different the moment you leave the room.

strTitle: Label Your Enemy as a Scold
strDesc: [us] says [3rd] is an arrogant, holier-than-thou nitpick who would make a better school marm than a spacer.
[us] asks [them] what hole they crawled out of.
[us] says that they made enough on their last job to buy a place on Tharsis Landing. Not that a backwater scrapper like [them] would know where that is.
[us] says they have been too busy with their new cushy contract to spend their time kicking around in a dump like this.
[us] says they've been shacked up with a new flame, and that [them] looks a little lonely by contrast.
[us] says they've been working on their new ship, class A rated, and asks what kind of deathtrap [them] has been drifting around in.
[us] says they have more important things to do than banter with spacer trash.

[us] agrees to disembark.
[us] says this is their ship! No way.

[us] agrees to stop following [them].
